title: 103_hr3464
content: The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes funds for the modernization of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System. The Forest Service is required to study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Additionally, the Act includes increased criminal penalties for arsonists. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property under section 844 of title 18, United States Code. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment up to 10 years, with harsher penalties if damage exceeds $1,000,000 or if lives are endangered. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" enhances penalties for arson and explosives offenses on federal property. Offenders can receive fines and imprisonment ranging from 8 to 40 years based on the extent of damage or harm caused. In cases of death, offenders may face a fine, imprisonment exceeding 25 years, or even the death penalty. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code, introduces penalties for reckless conduct resulting in property damage or injury. The Forest Service will study federal legal impediments to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress. The Secretary of Defense will report on using military resources for firefighting. Additionally, there will be a report on insuring firefighting water supply and backup power. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire chiefs and experts, will study the feasibility of improving water supply and backup power for firefighting in national forest areas. Results will be reported to Congress within a year. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost loans for the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994-1998.
